tenant_id.description:
The ID of the tenant. A tenant is also known as an account
 or project.

actions.name: Find stack
actions.description:
Finds the canonical URL for a specified stack.
 
 
 Also works with verbs other than GET, so you can perform PUT
 and DELETE operations on a current stack. Set your client to
 follow redirects. Note that when redirecting, the request method
 should not change, as defined in RFC2626. However, in many clients
 the default behavior is to change the method to GET when you
 receive a 302 because this behavior is ubiquitous in web browsers.

tenant_id.description:
The ID of the tenant. A tenant is also known as an account
 or project.

actions.name: Find stack resources
actions.description:
Finds the canonical URL for the resource list of a specified
 stack.
 
 
 The canonical URL is returned for only non-deleted stacks. To
 fetch the resource list for deleted stacks, use the following
 endpoint:
 
 /v1/{tenant_id}/stacks/{stack_name}/{stack_id}/resources

responses.description: Lists resources for the specified stack in JSON format.

tenant_id.description:
The ID of the tenant. A tenant is also known as an account
 or project.

actions.name: Find stack events
actions.description:
Finds the canonical URL for the event list of a specified
 stack.

actions.name: Abandon stack
actions.description:
Deletes a specified stack but leaves its resources intact, and
 returns data describing the stack and its resources.

tenant_id.description:
The ID of the tenant. A tenant is also known as an account
 or project.

actions.name: Snapshot stack
actions.description:
Takes a snapshot of all the resources in the stack. All
 snapshots are deleted upon deletion of the stack.

actions.name: List snapshots
actions.description: Lists the stack snapshots.

 or project.

 or project.

actions.name: Restore snapshot
actions.description:
Restores a stack snapshot. You can restore only active stacks
 from a snapshot. Deleted stacks must be recreated.

actions.name: Send a signal to a resource
actions.description:
Sends a signal to a specified resource.
 
 
 The contents of the request body depends on the resource to
 which you send a signal.
 
 
 Some resources cannot receive signals. If you send them a
 signal, they return a 400 error code.

type_name.description: The name of a resource type.

actions.name: Show resource schema
actions.description:
Shows the interface schema for a specified resource type.
 This schema describes the properties that can be set on
 the resource, their types, constraints, descriptions, and
 default values. Additionally, the resource attributes and
 their descriptions are provided.

tenant_id.description:
The ID of the tenant. A tenant is also known as an account
 or project.

type_name.description: The name of a resource type.

actions.name: Show resource template
actions.description:
Shows the template representation for a specified resource type.
 
 
 The returned template contains a single resource of the specified
 type. Each resource property is mapped to a template parameter and
 each resource attribute is mapped to a template output.
 
 
 You can use these templates as a starting place for creating
 customized, template-based resources or as examples of using the
 particular resource in another template.
 
 
 Use the template_type query parameter to specify the
 resource template type. Default type is cfn. The
 hot template type is supported. For example:
 
 /v1/{tenant_id}/resource_types/{type_name}/template?template_type=cfn

template_type.description:
The resource template type. Default type is
 cfn. The hot template type is supported.

actions.name: Show server configuration metadata
actions.description:
Shows the deployment configuration metadata for a specified
 server.
 
 
 Use the group property to specify the
 configuration hook to which the pass the metadata item.

tenant_id.description:

actions.name: Show orchestration engine status
actions.description:
Enables administrative users to view details for all orchestration
 engines.
 
 
 Orchestration engine details include engine_id, topic
 name, last updated time, health status, and host name.
 
 Troubleshooting
 
 
 
 A 503 error code indicates that the heat
 engines are not operational. Run the heat-manage
 service list command or contact your cloud
 provider to determine why the heat engines are not
 operational.

responses.description: All Orchestration engines are not operational.
You are not authorized to complete this action.
